messageBody:
Josh,

Remember the different levels of testing: unit, functional and user.

Unit testing:

> I would suggest creating a mock file. Something along these
> lines: [...]

Functional testing:

> Several options are available based on what your testing environment
> 1), 2), 3) [...]

For unit testing you would probably want your tests to exercise very
specific parts of the code, and therefore, you want the least
interaction possible with outside objects (see example below). Patterns
like self-shunt and Mock objects are well suited to this type of testing
(search archives for more info).

With functional testing you want to exercise specific test
cases/scenarios, within a specific environment. Setting up a known
directory structure with jars and checking the results would be a valid
functional test.

LEAST INTERACTION EXAMPLE:
Today I ran into a problem reading in files on a Solaris OS. The
application was running fine on windows, but as soon as it was moved to
the Solaris platform, some records were getting corrupted. The data we
were processing was a set of Spanish addresses, and contained extended
characters. We tracked the problem down to character mapping conversion
problems. The lesson learnt is: the problem came from environment
settings. The actual application worked fine, given the appropriate
input (i.e. Mocking up the InputStream). The problem came with the
environment settings.

HTH,

Manuel Amago.
